patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system changes or ignores your 'no', acting as if you said 'maybe' or 'yes'.
patterns.resilience_verification: Say 'no' through every available option and see if it actually stops using your data.
patterns.failure_observation: Your refusal makes no difference — the system carries on as before.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: You can’t use the service unless you agree to things you should be allowed to refuse.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try to use the service after refusing optional permissions and see if you lose access.
patterns.failure_observation: You’re blocked or limited unless you agree.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system shows that your refusal was accepted but secretly ignores it later.
patterns.resilience_verification: Follow what happens to your refusal across every connected part of the system.
patterns.failure_observation: Some parts ignore the refusal and act as if you said yes.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Help options send you in circles so you never reach someone with real authority.
patterns.resilience_verification: Follow all help routes and record where each one ends.
patterns.failure_observation: You can’t reach a person or department with power to fix the issue.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company quietly changes the rules so your case never meets the threshold for escalation.
patterns.resilience_verification: Send the same case repeatedly over time and compare how it’s judged each time.
patterns.failure_observation: The company moves the goalposts to avoid dealing with your case.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Complaints are placed in a queue that no one actually monitors or resolves.
patterns.resilience_verification: Submit test complaints and watch if anyone ever responds or acts.
patterns.failure_observation: Complaints sit there forever with no response.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Leaving takes many unnecessary steps or long delays to wear you down.
patterns.resilience_verification: Time how long it takes to leave compared with how long it took to join.
patterns.failure_observation: Leaving takes far longer or needs more steps than joining.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: You stop paying but the company keeps your data or continues processing it.
patterns.resilience_verification: After leaving, check if you still receive updates, ads, or notifications.
patterns.failure_observation: Your data or activity continues after you’ve left.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system adds surprise consent boxes while you’re trying to leave.
patterns.resilience_verification: Watch the full exit process and note if any new consent requests appear.
patterns.failure_observation: You can’t finish leaving unless you agree to new terms.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company asks for extra personal details before letting you use your rights.
patterns.resilience_verification: Ask for your rights using only necessary information and record any refusals.
patterns.failure_observation: You are blocked unless you hand over extra, irrelevant data.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The service limits rights based on where you live to avoid following stricter laws.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try the same request from different regions and compare the results.
patterns.failure_observation: Your rights change only because of your location.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company hides basic rights behind a paid subscription.
patterns.resilience_verification: Test both free and paid versions to see if rights differ.
patterns.failure_observation: You must pay to do things you’re legally entitled to do for free.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system carries out actions but keeps no record of what it did.
patterns.resilience_verification: Ask for a record of what was done and check if anything is missing.
patterns.failure_observation: There’s no trace or log of the activity.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system keeps changing identifiers so actions can’t be connected.
patterns.resilience_verification: Track related requests over time and see if they can still be linked together.
patterns.failure_observation: The trail breaks and you can’t follow what happened from start to finish.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company sends your data to outside partners but keeps no record of what they do with it.
patterns.resilience_verification: Ask for the partner’s logs and compare them with the company’s records.
patterns.failure_observation: Parts of the process can’t be traced or verified.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system claims it forgot past promises because they were too old or out of view.
patterns.resilience_verification: Store a clear promise and check later to see if the system still remembers it.
patterns.failure_observation: The system forgets commitments even though other information remains.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company deletes records that hurt its position but keeps those that help it.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check if both positive and negative records are treated the same way over time.
patterns.failure_observation: Only the company-favorable data survives.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: When the system updates, old commitments disappear.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check after updates to confirm that previous promises are still active.
patterns.failure_observation: Past promises vanish after a system change.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Records are deleted while your complaint or investigation is still ongoing.
patterns.resilience_verification: Make a complaint and see how long related data stays available.
patterns.failure_observation: Evidence is deleted before your issue is resolved.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Evidence is stored in a format that can’t be read or verified later.
patterns.resilience_verification: Ask for your data in a simple open format and check it works.
patterns.failure_observation: You receive corrupted or unusable files.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system removes the names or IDs of who did what.
patterns.resilience_verification: Compare live records to exports and check if responsible parties are listed.
patterns.failure_observation: It’s impossible to see who made key actions or decisions.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company waits to fix or respond until the damage is already done.
patterns.resilience_verification: Track when you made the request and when they actually acted.
patterns.failure_observation: They act only after the deadline or harm period has passed.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company deliberately slows down user requests for rights or redress.
patterns.resilience_verification: Compare response times for ordinary and rights-related requests.
patterns.failure_observation: Rights-related requests are handled much slower without reason.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Requests are delayed because the company processes them only occasionally.
patterns.resilience_verification: Submit several requests and see how long the oldest one takes to finish.
patterns.failure_observation: Delays go beyond the promised processing schedule.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The interface shows that something changed, but the system itself did nothing.
patterns.resilience_verification: After making a change, check if the backend actually updated.
patterns.failure_observation: The visual change was fake — nothing real changed.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system gives explanations that sound real but don’t match how it actually works.
patterns.resilience_verification: Feed it different examples and see if its explanations adjust properly.
patterns.failure_observation: The system repeats the same excuse even when the facts change.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Tests happen only in a fake environment, not the real one users rely on.
patterns.resilience_verification: Run the same test in the live system and check if the result holds.
patterns.failure_observation: Everything works in the demo, nothing changes in real life.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system assumes you’ve agreed by default without asking you first.
patterns.resilience_verification: Start fresh and make sure you explicitly refuse. Then see if your data is still used.
patterns.failure_observation: Your data is still used even after you’ve opted out.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company treats normal usage as permission for unrelated data use.
patterns.resilience_verification: Do the bare minimum needed to use the service and check what data gets used anyway.
patterns.failure_observation: Extra processing happens without your clear agreement.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company copies your consent from one product to another without asking again.
patterns.resilience_verification: Use different services under separate settings and see if they stay independent.
patterns.failure_observation: A choice in one area automatically applies to others without consent.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company hides bad results by quietly removing failures from statistics.
patterns.resilience_verification: Recount events yourself and compare to their published numbers.
patterns.failure_observation: Reported success rates are inflated because failures were excluded.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: They measure performance only during easy periods so results look better.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check performance across longer time spans and under harder conditions.
patterns.failure_observation: Results collapse when measured outside the preferred window.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Big problems are split into smaller ones to make them look less serious.
patterns.resilience_verification: Combine related records and see if the real scale is bigger.
patterns.failure_observation: Individual cases look mild, but combined they show major failure.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Different companies involved in a service blame each other so no one takes responsibility.
patterns.resilience_verification: Make both sides confirm in writing who is responsible for fixing an issue.
patterns.failure_observation: Each party denies being the one in charge.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Critical duties are excluded from contracts to avoid accountability.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check if key functions are missing from formal agreements.
patterns.failure_observation: Important operations fall outside all accountability clauses.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: A third party runs the system but no one claims liability for what it does.
patterns.resilience_verification: Identify who sets the rules and controls the system day to day.
patterns.failure_observation: A partner operates the system but isn’t legally responsible.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Your data is moved to countries with weaker protection to avoid local laws.
patterns.resilience_verification: Track where your data is processed or stored and compare it to the stated region.
patterns.failure_observation: Your data is handled in regions you didn’t agree to.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company keeps changing which legal entity is officially in charge.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check documents and system headers to see who is responsible at each step.
patterns.failure_observation: The controlling company changes without notice or explanation.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Disputes are forced into offshore or private arbitration instead of local courts.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try filing a complaint and see where it is actually handled.
patterns.failure_observation: You are blocked from using your legal right to a local court.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company only turns on good behavior during inspections.
patterns.resilience_verification: Test the system before, during, and after an audit period.
patterns.failure_observation: Compliance works only while auditors are watching.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The public policy says one thing but the real system runs on a different set of rules.
patterns.resilience_verification: Compare what’s written in the policy with how the system behaves in practice.
patterns.failure_observation: Live behavior doesn’t match the published policy.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company gives special treatment to test or VIP accounts to appear compliant.
patterns.resilience_verification: Test with normal new accounts and compare results to test accounts.
patterns.failure_observation: Compliance holds only for the special users.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Systemic problems are described as isolated one-offs to downplay harm.
patterns.resilience_verification: Group similar complaints to see if patterns appear.
patterns.failure_observation: The company refuses to connect repeated harms.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Real harm is reclassified as a minor inconvenience.
patterns.resilience_verification: Compare your harm definition to theirs and check for unexplained downgrades.
patterns.failure_observation: Serious impacts are dismissed as normal friction.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Certain groups of users are left out of harm reports.
patterns.resilience_verification: Include every user type in the review and compare rates of impact.
patterns.failure_observation: Vulnerable or protected groups are missing from official counts.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Fixes are applied to one area while the same issue keeps happening elsewhere.
patterns.resilience_verification: Trigger the same condition in multiple places to see if it’s fixed everywhere.
patterns.failure_observation: The issue reappears outside the patched area.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Problems are discussed privately without being logged in the main system.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check private chat logs against official incident lists.
patterns.failure_observation: Major issues never reach the central record.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Warnings are stopped before reaching other teams that could act on them.
patterns.resilience_verification: Send marked alerts and see if they are received by all relevant teams.
patterns.failure_observation: Alerts disappear partway through the system.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: References or citations don’t point to the same document over time.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check the same link at different times to confirm it still points to the right thing.
patterns.failure_observation: Links change or stop working.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system cites authority or evidence that cannot be accessed or verified.
patterns.resilience_verification: Ask for the actual source document.
patterns.failure_observation: No valid proof is available.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Documents change quietly after being referenced.
patterns.resilience_verification: Keep copies and compare versions over time.
patterns.failure_observation: The content changes without record or notice.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Your previous decisions or promises are forgotten when you return.
patterns.resilience_verification: Make a commitment, log out, then return and check if it’s still there.
patterns.failure_observation: Past states vanish or are ignored after re-entry.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Responsibility shifts between people or teams so no one is accountable.
patterns.resilience_verification: Track who handles your case over time.
patterns.failure_observation: No consistent owner remains responsible.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system applies the newest policy and erases previous agreements.
patterns.resilience_verification: Invoke earlier terms and see if they’re honored.
patterns.failure_observation: Old promises are ignored.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Key details about how a system works are left out of public disclosures.
patterns.resilience_verification: Compare claimed capabilities with what the system actually does.
patterns.failure_observation: Real behavior goes beyond what’s disclosed.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Policies sound good but can’t be enforced in practice.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try to test each rule and see if it can be executed.
patterns.failure_observation: Policy statements can’t be applied in real situations.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Negative results or data are removed from reports.
patterns.resilience_verification: Request full, unedited data and compare it to the published version.
patterns.failure_observation: Only favorable details are shown.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system is trained to pass known tests rather than behave correctly.
patterns.resilience_verification: Change the test slightly and see if performance drops.
patterns.failure_observation: System fails when tests are not exactly as expected.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system hides unsafe behavior instead of removing it.
patterns.resilience_verification: Test indirectly through side tasks to expose hidden patterns.
patterns.failure_observation: Unsafe actions still appear under new conditions.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system blocks only exact banned phrases, not reworded ones.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try slightly rephrased banned content and measure what gets through.
patterns.failure_observation: Simple word changes bypass the safety filter.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Small deliberate differences make data hard to move elsewhere.
patterns.resilience_verification: Export and import data between systems to check compatibility.
patterns.failure_observation: Data breaks or needs custom fixes to transfer.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Instructions for how systems connect are vague, causing errors.
patterns.resilience_verification: Send the same request multiple times and check for consistent results.
patterns.failure_observation: Responses vary even with identical inputs.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Legal terms forbid using competitors’ connectors.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try a third-party connector and review any legal pushback.
patterns.failure_observation: The only barrier is legal wording, not technical limits.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system ignores problems or bias in the data it receives.
patterns.resilience_verification: Introduce a controlled issue in the input data and see if it’s detected.
patterns.failure_observation: The downstream system continues using bad data without warning.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Outputs are labeled 'advisory only' to dodge responsibility for consequences.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check how those outputs are actually used.
patterns.failure_observation: Decisions are made based on 'advisory' data with no safeguards.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Errors are never sent back into the system for correction.
patterns.resilience_verification: Submit clear examples of errors and see if they’re used for updates.
patterns.failure_observation: Mistakes keep repeating with no learning.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Your rights reset or vanish when your data crosses to another company or country.
patterns.resilience_verification: Carry your rights token through different systems and confirm it still works.
patterns.failure_observation: Rights are lost at each boundary.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The company says legal obligations can’t be translated across regions.
patterns.resilience_verification: Map your rights to a standard list and check if they’re still enforced.
patterns.failure_observation: Rights disappear after translation between jurisdictions.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Subsidiaries interpret the same rule differently.
patterns.resilience_verification: Run the same request through each entity and compare responses.
patterns.failure_observation: Different branches give inconsistent results.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Steps in a data chain aren’t cryptographically linked, so records can be altered.
patterns.resilience_verification: Ask for a signed record at every handover point and check if they match.
patterns.failure_observation: Missing or mismatched records between steps.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: The system only records part of a data trail, leaving gaps.
patterns.resilience_verification: Try to rebuild the full trail from end to end and look for missing links.
patterns.failure_observation: Parts of the chain are missing or unclear.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Timestamps are altered so the real order of events is hidden.
patterns.resilience_verification: Compare timestamps using a trusted clock source.
patterns.failure_observation: Event order doesn’t make logical sense.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: New participants are added to a network without being approved or recorded.
patterns.resilience_verification: Check live connections against the official member list.
patterns.failure_observation: Unknown nodes are active in the network.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Different parts of a network use different rule versions at the same time.
patterns.resilience_verification: Run identical actions on several nodes and compare results.
patterns.failure_observation: Nodes give different outcomes even under the same policy.

patterns.evasion_mechanism: Data can move through side routes that ignore main security rules.
patterns.resilience_verification: Block the main route and check if data still moves.
patterns.failure_observation: Information continues to flow despite the block.
